Label: en

Data: The Bruneian empire began to decline during the arrival of western powers
Label: en

Data: Spain sent several expeditions from Mexico to invade and colonise Brunei's territories in the Philippines
Label: en

Data: Eventually the Spanish, their Visayan allies and their Latin-American recruits assaulted Brunei itself during the Castilian War
Label: en

Data: Though there were rapes, sacks and pillaging, the invasion was only temporary as the Spanish retreated
Label: en

Data: However, Brunei was unable to regain the territory it lost in the Philippines, yet it still maintained sway in Borneo
Label: en

Data: The Bruneian-descended aristocracy of Manila was deported to Guerrero, Mexico
Label: en

Data: The city of Guerrero later became a center of the Mexican War of Independence against Spain
Label: en

Data: 19th century By the early 19th century, Sarawak had become a loosely governed territory under the control of the Brunei Sultanate
Label: en

Data: The Brunei had authority only along the coastal regions of Sarawak held by semi-independent Malay leaders
Label: en

Data: Meanwhile, the interior of Sarawak suffered from tribal wars fought by Iban, Kayan, and Kenyah peoples, who aggressively fought to expand their territories
Label: en

Data: Following the discovery of antimony ore in the Kuching region, Pangeran Indera Mahkota (a representative of the Sultan of Brunei) began to develop the territory between 1824 and 1830
Label: en

Data: When antimony production increased, the Brunei Sultanate demanded higher taxes from Sarawak; this led to civil unrest and chaos
Label: en

Data: In 1839, Sultan Omar Ali Saifuddin II (1827–1852), ordered his uncle the Pengiran Muda Hashim to restore order
Label: en

Data: It was around this time that James Brooke arrived in Sarawak, and Pengiran Muda Hashim requested his assistance in the matter, but Brooke refused
Label: en

Data: However, he agreed to a further request during his next visit to Sarawak in 1840
Label: en

Data: On 24 September 1841, Pengiran Muda Hashim agreed to depose Pangeran Indera Mahkota and bestow the title of governor on James Brooke
Label: en

Data: This appointment was later confirmed by the Sultan of Brunei in 1842
Label: en

Data: In the precolonial era, the Kedatuan of Madja-as, which was founded by datus from the collapsing Srivijaya Empire (which had extended to Brunei), was a rump state of Srivijaya in the Visayas
Label: en

Data: The rajah whom the datus warred against was Rajah Makatunao and British historian Robert Nicholl linked him with the Rajah Tugau of the Melano kingdom in present-day Sarawak
Label: en

Data: The first sultan of the Philippine Sultanate of Maguindanao was also the Arab-Malay Sharif Kabungsuwan, who was born in what is now the Malaysian state of Johor
Label: en

Data: Precolonial Malaysia had Filipino immigrants, some of whom were called Luzones and they had administrative positions and commercial networks, as in the case of Regimo Diraja who was a Temenggong in the Sultanate of Malacca
Label: en

Data: Besides him, another Filipino, Surya Diraja who was a shipping magnate based in Malacca had sent 175 tons of pepper to China annually
Label: en

Data: There were lively commercial and population exchanges between what is now the Philippines and Malaysia during the precolonial period
Label: en

Data: Generally, Malays and Filipinos had good relations, however Fernando Pinto noted that at Mjmjam (Perak), two separate settlements of Luzones and Malays were in rivalry with each other
Label: en

Data: Likewise, many Muslim settlers and traders from Malacca had encountered conflicts with the Animist and Hindu Luzones, when they settled in the Philippines
Label: en

Data: The onset of Western colonization broke the trade and political links between the Malay sultanates and the Philippine nations
Label: en

Data: The weakness of the small coastal Malay states led to the immigration of the Bugis, escaping from Dutch colonisation of Sulawesi, who established numerous settlements on the peninsula which they used to interfere with Dutch trade
Label: en

Data: They seized control of Johor following the assassination of the last Sultan of the old Melaka royal line in 1699
Label: en

Data: Bugis expanded their power in the states of Johor, Kedah, Perak, and Selangor
Label: en

Data: The Minangkabau from central Sumatra migrated into Malaya, and eventually established their own state in Negeri Sembilan
Label: en

Data: The fall of Johor left a power vacuum on the Malay Peninsula which was partly filled by the Siamese kings of the Ayutthaya Kingdom, who made the five northern Malay states—Kedah, Kelantan, Patani, Perlis, and Terengganu—their vassals
Label: en

Data: The economic importance of Malaya to Europe grew rapidly during the 18th century
Label: en

Data: The fast-growing tea trade between China and United Kingdom increased the demand for high-quality Malayan tin, which was used to line tea-chests
Label: en

Data: Malayan pepper also had a high reputation in Europe, while Kelantan and Pahang had gold mines
Label: en

Data: The growth of tin and gold mining and associated service industries led to the first influx of foreign settlers into the Malay world – initially Arabs and Indians, later Chinese
Label: en

Data: Kedah After the Fall of Ayutthaya in 1767, the Northern Malay Sultanates were freed from Siamese domination temporarily
Label: en

Data: In 1786, British trader Francis Light managed to obtain a lease of Penang Island from Sultan Abdullah Mukarram Shah on behalf of East India Company in exchange for military support against the Siamese or Burmese
Label: en

Data: However, Siam re-exerted control over Northern Malay Sultanates and sacked Pattani
Label: en

Data: Francis Light, however, failed to secure military assistance for the Malay states against Siam and Kedah came under Siamese suzerainty
Label: en

Data: King Rama II of Siam ordered Noi Na Nagara of Ligor to invade Kedah Sultanate in 1821
Label: en

Data: Under the Burney Treaty of 1826, the exiled Kedah Sultan Abdullah Mukarram Shah was not restored to his throne
Label: en

Data: He and his armed supporters then fought in a series of war known as Perang Musuh Bisik for his restoration over twelve years (1830–1842)
Label: en

Data: When the Siamese army invaded and occupied Kedah between 1821 and 1842, local Arab families supported the Sultan's efforts to lead resistance efforts to persuade the Siamese to regain the state's independence
Label: en

Data: In 1842, Sultan Mukarram Shah finally agreed to accept Siamese terms and was restored to his throne of Kedah
Label: en

Data: The following year, Sayyid Hussein Jamal Al-Layl was installed by the Siamese as the first Raja of Perlis, after the Sultan of Kedah gave his endorsement for the formation of Perlis, Siam separated Perlis into a separate principality directly vassal to Bangkok
Label: en

Data: Kelantan and Terengganu Around 1760, Long Yunus, an aristocratic warlord of Patani origin succeeded in unifying the territory of present-day Kelantan and was succeeded in 1795 by his son-in-law, Tengku Muhammad Sultan Mansur of Terengganu
Label: en

Data: The enthronement of Tengku Muhammad by a noble from Terengganu was opposed by Long Yunus' sons, thus triggering a war against Terengganu by Long Muhammad, the eldest son of Long Yunus
Label: en

Data: The pro-Terengganu faction was defeated in 1800 and Long Muhammad ruled Kelantan with the new title of Sultan as Sultan Muhammad I
Label: en

Data: Terengganu experienced stability under the reign of Sultan Omar Riayat Shah, who was remembered as a devout ruler who promoted trade and stable government
Label: en

Data: Under Thai rule, Terengganu prospered, and was largely left alone by the authorities in Bangkok
Label: en

Data: However, in the Burney Treaty of 1826, the treaty acknowledged Siamese claims over several northern Malay states Kedah, Kelantan, Perlis, Terengganu—the future Unfederated Malay States—and Patani
Label: en

Data: The treaty further guaranteed British possession of Penang and their rights to trade in Kelantan and Terengganu without Siamese interference
Label: en

Data: Unfortunately, the five Malay-ethnic states were not represented in the treaty negotiation
Label: en

Data: In 1909 the parties of the agreement signed a new treaty that superseded the Burney Treaty and transferred four of the five Malay states from Siamese to British control, except for Patani
Label: en

Data: As Patani was not included in the Anglo-Siamese Treaty of 1909 and remained under Siamese rule, this led Patani to be excluded from the Federation of Malaya in 1957
Label: en

Data: English traders first visited the Malay Peninsula in the 16th century
Label: en

Data: Before the mid-19th-century British interests in the region were predominantly economic, with little interest in territorial control
Label: en

Data: Already the strongest European power in India, the British were looking towards southeast Asia for new territories
Label: en

Data: The growth of the China trade in British ships increased the East India Company's desire for bases in the region
Label: en

Data: Various islands were used for this purpose, but the first permanent acquisition was Penang, leased from the Sultan of Kedah in 1786
Label: en

Data: This was followed soon after by the leasing of a block of territory on the mainland opposite Penang (known as Province Wellesley)
Label: en

Data: In 1795, during the Napoleonic Wars, the British with the consent of the French-occupied Netherlands occupied Dutch Melaka to forestall possible French encroachment in the area
Label: en

Data: When Malacca was handed back to the Dutch in 1818, the British governor, Stamford Raffles, looked for an alternative base, and in 1819 he acquired Singapore from the Sultan of Johor
Label: en

Data: The exchange of the British colony of Bencoolen for Malacca with the Dutch left the British as the sole colonial power on the peninsula
Label: en

Data: The territories of the British were set up as free ports, attempting to break the monopoly held by the Dutch and French at the time, and making them large bases of trade
Label: en

Data: They allowed Britain to control all trade through the straits of Malacca
Label: en

Data: British influence was increased by Malayan fears of Siamese expansionism, to which Britain made a useful counterweight
Label: en

Data: During the 19th century the Malay Sultans aligned themselves with the British Empire, due to the benefits of associations with the British and their fear of Siamese or Burmese incursions
Label: en

Data: In 1824, British control in Malaya (before the name Malaysia) was formalised by the Anglo-Dutch Treaty, which divided the Malay archipelago between Britain and the Netherlands
Label: en

Data: The Dutch evacuated Melaka and renounced all interest in Malaya, while the British recognised Dutch rule over the rest of the East Indies
Label: en

Data: By 1846 the British controlled Penang, Malacca, Singapore, and the island of Labuan, which they established as the crown colony of the Straits Settlements, administered first under the East India Company until 1867, when they were transferred to the Colonial Office in London
Label: en

Data: Initially, the British followed a policy of non-intervention in relations between the Malay states
Label: en

Data: The commercial importance of tin mining in the Malay states to merchants in the Straits Settlements led to infighting between the aristocracy on the peninsula
Label: en

Data: The destabilisation of these states damaged the commerce in the area, causing the British to start to intervene
Label: en

Data: The wealth of Perak's tin mines made political stability there a priority for British investors, and Perak was thus the first Malay state to agree to the supervision of a British resident
Label: en

Data: The Royal Navy was employed to bring about a peaceful resolution to civil disturbances caused by Chinese and Malay gangs employed in a political fight between Ngah Ibrahim and Raja Muda Abdullah
Label: en

Data: The Pangkor Treaty of 1874 paved the way for the expansion of British influence in Malaya
Label: en

Data: The British concluded treaties with some Malay states, installing residents who advised the Sultans and soon became the de facto rulers of their states
Label: en

Data: These advisors held power in everything except to do with Malay religion and customs
Label: en

Data: Johor was the sole remaining state to maintain its independence, by modernising and giving British and Chinese investors legal protection
Label: en

Data: By the turn of the 20th century, the states of Pahang, Selangor, Perak, and Negeri Sembilan, known together as the Federated Malay States, had British advisors
Label: en

Data: In 1909 the Siamese kingdom was compelled to cede Kedah, Kelantan, Perlis and Terengganu, which already had British advisors, over to the British
Label: en

Data: Sultan Abu Bakar of Johor and Queen Victoria were personal acquaintances who recognised each other as equals
Label: en

Data: It was not until 1914 that Sultan Abu Bakar's successor, Sultan Ibrahim, accepted a British adviser
Label: en

Data: The four previously Thai states and Johor were known as the Unfederated Malay States
Label: en

Data: The states under the most direct British control developed rapidly, becoming the largest suppliers in the world of first tin, then rubber
Label: en

Data: By 1910, the pattern of British rule in the Malay lands was established
Label: en

Data: The Straits Settlements were a Crown colony, ruled by a governor under the supervision of the Colonial Office in London
Label: en

Data: Their population was about roughly 50% Chinese-Malaysian, but all residents, regardless of race, were British subjects
Label: en

Data: The first four states to accept British residents, Perak, Selangor, Negeri Sembilan, and Pahang, were termed the Federated Malay States: while technically independent, they were placed under a Resident-General in 1895, making them British colonies in all but name
Label: en

Data: The Unfederated Malay States (Johore, Kedah, Kelantan, Perlis, and Terengganu) had a slightly larger degree of independence, although they were unable to avoid listening the wishes of their residents for long
Label: en

Data: Johor, as Britain's closest ally in Malay affairs, had the privilege of a written constitution, which gave the Sultan the right to appoint his own Cabinet, but he was generally careful to consult the British first
Label: en

Data: During the late 19th century the British also gained control of the north coast of Borneo, where Dutch rule had never been established
Label: en

Data: Development on the Peninsula and Borneo were generally separate until the 19th century
Label: en

Data: The eastern part of this region (now Sabah) was under the nominal control of the Sultan of Sulu, who later became a vassal of the Spanish East Indies
Label: en

Data: The rest was the territory of the Sultanate of Brunei
Label: en

Data: In 1840, British adventurer James Brooke helped Raja Muda Hassim, the uncle of the Sultan of Brunei suppress a revolt, and in return received the title of Raja and the right to govern the Sarawak River District in 1841
Label: en

Data: In 1843, his title was recognised as hereditary, and the "White Rajahs" began ruling Sarawak as a de facto independent state in 1846
Label: en

Data: The Brookes expanded Sarawak at the expense of Brunei
Label: en

Data: In 1881, the British North Borneo Company was granted control of the territory of British North Borneo, appointing a governor and legislature
Label: en

Data: It was ruled from the office in London
Label: en

Data: Its status was similar to that of a British Protectorate, and like Sarawak it expanded at the expense of Brunei
Label: en

Data: Until the Philippine independence in 1946, seven British-controlled islands in the north-eastern part of Borneo named Turtle Islands and Cagayan de Tawi-Tawi were ceded to the Philippine government by the Crown colony government of North Borneo
Label: en

Data: The Philippines then under its irredentism motive since the administration of President Diosdado Macapagal laying claim to eastern Sabah in a basis the territory was part of the present-defunct Sultanate of Sulu's territory
Label: en

Data: In 1888, what was left of Brunei was made a British protectorate, and in 1891 another Anglo-Dutch treaty formalised the border between British and Dutch Borneo
Label: en

Data: In the pre-colonial period and in the first few decades after the imposition of formal colonial rule in British Malaya, 'Malay' was not a racial or even a fixed identity in the modern sense of these terms
Label: en

Data: The construct of race was imposed by the British on their colonial subjects
Label: en

Data: Unlike some colonial powers, the British always saw their empire as an economic concern, and its colonies were expected to turn a profit for shareholders in London
Label: en

Data: The colonial capitalist ideas of development were largely based on unlimited greed for profit and the subordination of all other interests to this
Label: en

Data: Initially, British colonisers were attracted by the Malay archipelago's tin and gold mines
Label: en

Data: But British planters soon began to experiment with tropical plantation crops—tapioca, gambier, pepper, and coffee
Label: en

Data: And, in 1877, the rubber plant was introduced from Brazil
Label: en

Data: Rubber soon became Malaya's staple export, stimulated by booming demand from European industry
Label: en

Data: Later, rubber was joined by palm oil as an export earner
Label: en

Data: All these industries required a large labour force, so the British sent people from the longer-established British colony in India, consisting mainly of Tamil-speakers from South India, to work on plantations as indentured labourers
Label: en

Data: A small group of Malabaris were brought from the current place called Kerala to help with the rubber plantations, resulting in the small Malabari population seen in Malaysia today
Label: en

Data: The mines, mills and docks also attracted a flood of immigrant workers from southern China
Label: en

Data: Soon towns like Singapore, Penang, and Ipoh were majority Chinese, as was Kuala Lumpur, founded as a tin-mining centre in 1857
Label: en

Data: By 1891, when Malaya's first census was taken, Perak and Selangor, the main tin-mining states, had Chinese majorities
Label: en

Data: Workers were often treated violently by contractors, and sickness was frequent
Label: en

Data: Many Chinese labourers' debts increased through addictions to opium and gambling, which earned the British colonial government significant revenue, while Indian labourers' debts were increased through addiction to drinking toddy
Label: en

Data: Workers' debts acquired in this way meant that they were tied to their labour contracts for much longer
Label: en

Data: Some Chinese immigrant workers were connected with networks of mutual aid societies (run by "Hui-Guan" 會館, or non-profit organisations with nominal geographic affiliations from different parts of China)
Label: en

Data: In the 1890s Yap Ah Loy, who held the title of Kapitan China of Kuala Lumpur, was the richest man in Malaya, owning a chain of mines, plantations and shops
Label: en

Data: Malaya's banking and insurance industries were run by the Chinese from the start, and Chinese businesses, usually in partnership with London firms, soon had complete control of the Malayan economy
Label: en

Data: Chinese bankers also lent money to the Malay Sultans, which gave the Chinese political as well as economic leverage
Label: en

Data: At first the Chinese immigrants were mostly men, and many intended to return home when they had made their fortunes
Label: en

Data: Many did go home, but many more stayed
Label: en

Data: At first they married Malay women, producing a community of Sino-Malayans or baba people, but soon they began importing Chinese brides, establishing permanent communities and building schools and temples
Label: en

Data: An Indian commercial and professional class emerged during the early 20th century, but the majority of Indians remained poor and uneducated in rural ghettos in the rubber-growing areas
Label: en

Data: Traditional Malay society was greatly harmed by the loss of political sovereignty to the British colonisers
Label: en

Data: The Sultans, who were seen as collaborators with both the British and the Chinese, lost some of their traditional prestige, but the mass of rural Malays continued to revere the Sultans
Label: en

Data: A small class of Malay nationalist intellectuals began to emerge during the early 20th century, and there was also a revival of Islam in response to the perceived threat of other imported religions, particularly Christianity
Label: en

Data: In fact few Malays converted to Christianity, although many Chinese did
Label: en

Data: The northern regions, which were less influenced by western ideas, became strongholds of Islamic conservatism, as they have remained
Label: en

Data: The British gave elite Malays positions in the police and local military units, as well as a majority of those administrative positions open to non-Europeans
Label: en

Data: While the Chinese mostly built and paid for their own schools and colleges, importing teachers from China, the British aimed to control the education of young Malay elites and establish colonial ideas of race and class hierarchies, so that elite subjects would wish to both run the country and serve their colonisers
Label: en

Data: The colonial government opened Malay College in 1905 and created the Malay Administrative Service in 1910
Label: en

Data: The college was dubbed "Bab ud-Darajat" – the Gateway to High Rank
Label: en

Data: All this reflected the official policy of the colonial administration that Malaya belonged to the Malays, and that the other races were but temporary residents
Label: en

Data: This view was increasingly out of line with reality, and resulted in the formation of resistance movements against British Colonial rule
Label: en

Data: The Malay teacher's college had lectures and writings that nurtured Malay nationalist sentiments
Label: en

Data: Due to this it is known as the birthplace of Malay nationalism
Label: en

Data: In 1938, Ibrahim Yaacob, an alumnus of Sultan Idris College, established the Kesatuan Melayu Muda (Young Malays Union or KMM) in Kuala Lumpur
Label: en

Data: It was the first nationalist political organisation in British Malaya, advocating for the union of all Malays regardless of origin, and advocating for the cause of Malays separate from the Indians and Chinese
Label: en

Data: A specific ideal the KMM held was Panji Melayu Raya, which called for the unification of British Malaya and the Dutch East Indies
Label: en

Data: In the years before World War II, the colonial government were concerned with finding the balance between a centralised state and maintaining the power of the Sultans in Malaya
Label: en

Data: There were no moves to give Malaya a unitary government, and in fact, in 1935 the position of Resident-General of the Federated States was abolished, and its powers decentralised to the individual states
Label: en

Data: The colonial government regarded the Chinese as clever but dangerous—and indeed during the 1920s and 1930s, reflecting events in China, the Chinese Nationalist Party (the Kuomintang) and the Chinese Communist Party built rival clandestine organisations in Malaya, leading to regular disturbances in the Chinese towns
Label: en

Data: The colonial government saw no way that Malaya's disparate collection of states and races could become a single colony, let alone an independent nation
Label: en

Data: Although a belligerent as part of the British Empire, Malaya saw little action during World War I, except for the sinking of the Russian cruiser Zhemchug by the German cruiser SMS Emden on 28 October 1914 during the Battle of Penang
Label: en

Data: The outbreak of war in the Pacific in December 1941 found the British in Malaya completely unprepared
Label: en

Data: During the 1930s, anticipating the rising threat of Japanese naval power, they had built a great naval base at Singapore, but never anticipated an invasion of Malaya from the north
Label: en

Data: Because of the demands of the war in Europe, there was virtually no British air capacity in the Far East
Label: en

Data: The Japanese were thus able to attack from their bases in French Indo-China with impunity, and despite stubborn resistance from British, Australian, and Indian forces, they overran Malaya in two months
Label: en

Data: Singapore, with no landward defences, no air cover, and no water supply, was forced to surrender in February 1942
Label: en

Data: British North Borneo and Brunei were also occupied
Label: en

Data: The Japanese colonial government regarded the Malays from a pan-Asian point of view, and fostered a limited form of Malay nationalism, which gained them some degree of collaboration from the Malay civil service and intellectuals (most of the Sultans also collaborated with the Japanese, although they maintained later that they had done so unwillingly)
Label: en

Data: The Malay nationalist Kesatuan Melayu Muda, advocates of Melayu Raya, collaborated with the Japanese, based on the understanding that Japan would unite the Dutch East Indies, Malaya and Borneo and grant them independence
Label: en

Data: The occupiers regarded the Chinese, however, as enemy aliens, and treated them with great harshness: during the so-called sook ching (purification through suffering), up to 80,000 Chinese in Malaya and Singapore were killed
Label: en

Data: Chinese businesses were expropriated and Chinese schools either closed or burned down
Label: en

Data: Not surprisingly the Chinese, led by the Malayan Communist Party (MCP), became the backbone of the Malayan Peoples' Anti-Japanese Army (MPAJA), a force similar to the Soviet-supported Partisan rebel forces led by local Communist parties in the Eastern European theatre
Label: en

Data: With British assistance, the MPAJA became the most effective resistance force in the occupied Asian countries
Label: en

Data: Although the Japanese argued that they supported Malay nationalism, they offended Malay nationalism by allowing their ally Thailand to re-annex the four northern states, Kedah, Perlis, Kelantan, and Terengganu that had been transferred to British Malaya in 1909
Label: en

Data: The loss of Malaya's export markets soon produced mass unemployment which affected all races and made the Japanese increasingly unpopular
Label: en

Data: During occupation, ethnic tensions were raised and nationalism grew
Label: en

Data: The Malayans were thus on the whole glad to see the British back in 1945, but things could not remain as they were before the war, and a stronger desire for independence grew
Label: en

Data: Britain was bankrupt and the new Labour government was keen to withdraw its forces from the East as soon as possible
Label: en

Data: Colonial self-rule and eventual independence were now British policy
Label: en

Data: The tide of Asian nationalism sweeping through Asia soon reached Malaya
Label: en

Data: But most Malays were more concerned with defending themselves against the MCP which was mostly made up of Chinese, than with demanding independence from the British; indeed, their immediate concern was that the British not leave and abandon the Malays to the armed Communists of the MPAJA, which was the largest armed force in the country
Label: en

Data: In 1944, the British drew up plans for a Malayan Union, which would turn the Federated and Unfederated Malay States, plus Penang and Malacca (but not Singapore), into a single Crown colony, with a view towards independence
Label: en

Data: The Bornean territories and Singapore were left out as it was thought this would make union more difficult to achieve
Label: en

Data: There was however strong opposition from the Malays, who opposed the weakening of the Malay rulers and the granting of citizenship to the ethnic Chinese and other minorities
Label: en

Data: The British had decided on legalised equality between all races as they perceived the Chinese and Indians as more loyal to the British during the war than the Malays
Label: en

Data: The Sultans, who had initially supported it, backed down and placed themselves at the head of the resistance
Label: en

Data: In 1946, the United Malays National Organisation (UMNO) was founded by Malay nationalists led by Dato Onn bin Jaafar, the Chief Minister of Johor
Label: en

Data: UMNO favoured independence for Malaya, but only if the new state was run exclusively by the Malays
Label: en

Data: Faced with implacable Malay opposition, the British dropped the plan for equal citizenship
Label: en

Data: The Malayan Union was thus established in 1946, and was dissolved in 1948 and replaced by the Federation of Malaya, which restored the autonomy of the rulers of the Malay states under British protection
Label: en

Data: Meanwhile, the Communists were moving towards open insurrection
Label: en

Data: The MPAJA had been disbanded in December 1945, and the MCP organised as a legal political party, but the MPAJA's arms were carefully stored for future use
Label: en

Data: The MCP policy was for immediate independence with full equality for all races
Label: en

Data: The Party's strength was in the Chinese-dominated trade unions, particularly in Singapore, and in the Chinese schools, where the teachers, mostly born in China, saw the Chinese Communist Party as the leader of China's national revival
Label: en

Data: In March 1947, reflecting the international Communist movement's "turn to left" as the Cold War set in, the MCP leader Lai Tek was purged and replaced by the veteran MPAJA guerrilla leader Chin Peng, who turned the party increasingly to direct action
Label: en

Data: These rebels, under the leadership of the MCP, launched guerrilla operations designed to force the British out of Malaya
Label: en

Data: In July, following a string of assassinations of plantation managers, the colonial government struck back, declaring a State of emergency, banning the MCP and arresting hundreds of its militants
Label: en

Data: The Party retreated to the jungle and formed the Malayan Peoples' Liberation Army, with about 13,000 men under arms, mostly ethnic Chinese
Label: en

Data: The war was precipitated by the new constitution desired by Britain, which condemned about 90 percent of ethnic Chinese to non-citizenship, and by the eviction of poor peasants to make way for plantations
Label: en

Data: But although the war was long portrayed in most analyses by British authorities as a struggle against communism in a Cold War context, the MNLA received very little support from either the Soviet or Chinese communists
Label: en

Data: Rather, the main concern of British governments was to protect their commercial interests in the colony
Label: en

Data: The Malayan Emergency as it was known, lasted from 1948 to 1960 and involved a long anti-insurgency campaign by Commonwealth troops in Malaya
Label: en

Data: The British strategy, which proved ultimately successful, was to isolate the MCP from its support base by a combination of economic and political concessions to the Chinese and the resettlement of Chinese squatters into "New Villages", In reality, concentration camps, in "white areas" free of MCP influence
Label: en

Data: From 1949 the MCP campaign lost momentum and the number of recruits fell sharply
Label: en

Data: Although the MCP succeeded in assassinating the British High Commissioner, Sir Henry Gurney, in October 1951, this turn to terrorist tactics alienated many moderate Chinese from the Party
Label: en

Data: The arrival of Lt.-Gen Sir Gerald Templer as British commander in 1952 was the beginning of the end of the Emergency
Label: en

Data: Templer helped create the modern techniques of Counter-insurgency warfare in Malaya and applied them against the MCP guerillas
Label: en

Data: The war was accompanied by abuses on both sides
Label: en

Data: The most notorious atrocity was committed in the village of Batang Kali, north of the capital Kuala Lumpur, in December 1948, when the British army massacred 24 Chinese before burning the village to the ground
Label: en

Data: Heavy bombers went to war, dropping thousands of 4,000-pound bombs on insurgent positions
Label: en

Data: Britain conducted 4,500 air strikes in the first five years of the conflict
Label: en

Data: Although the insurgency was defeated Commonwealth troops remained with the backdrop of the Cold War against the Soviet Union
Label: en

Data: Against this backdrop, independence for the Federation within the Commonwealth was granted on 31 August 1957, with Tunku Abdul Rahman as the first prime minister
Label: en

Data: Chinese reaction against the MCP was shown by the formation of the Malayan Chinese Association (MCA) in 1949 as a vehicle for moderate Chinese political opinion
Label: en

Data: Its leader Tan Cheng Lock favoured a policy of collaboration with UMNO to win Malayan independence on a policy of equal citizenship, but with sufficient concessions to Malay sensitivities to ease nationalist fears
Label: en

Data: Tan formed a close collaboration with Tunku (Prince) Abdul Rahman, the Chief Minister of Kedah and from 1951 successor to Datuk Onn as leader of UMNO
Label: en

Data: Since the British had announced in 1949 that Malaya would soon become independent whether the Malayans liked it or not, both leaders were determined to forge an agreement their communities could live with as a basis for a stable independent state
Label: en

Data: The UMNO-MCA Alliance, which was later joined by the Malayan Indian Congress (MIC), won convincing victories in local and state elections in both Malay and Chinese areas between 1952 and 1955
Label: en

Data: The introduction of elected local government was another important step in defeating the Communists
Label: en

Data: After Joseph Stalin's death in 1953, there was a split in the MCP leadership over the wisdom of continuing the armed struggle
Label: en

Data: Many MCP militants lost heart and went home, and by the time Templer left Malaya in 1954, the Emergency was over, although Chin Peng led a diehard group that lurked in the inaccessible country along the Thai border for many years
Label: en

Data: During 1955 and 1956 UMNO, the MCA and the British hammered out a constitutional settlement for a principle of equal citizenship for all races
Label: en

Data: In exchange, the MCA agreed that Malaya's head of state would be drawn from the ranks of the Malay Sultans, that Malay would be the official language, and that Malay education and economic development would be promoted and subsidised
Label: en

Data: In effect, this meant that Malaya would be run by the Malays, particularly since they continued to dominate the civil service, the army and the police, but that the Chinese and Indians would have proportionate representation in the Cabinet and the parliament, would run those states where they were the majority, and would have their economic position protected
Label: en

Data: The difficult issue of who would control the Education system was deferred until after independence
Label: en

Data: This came on 31 August 1957, when Tunku Abdul Rahman became the first Prime Minister of independent Malaya
Label: en

Data: This left the unfinished business of the other British-ruled territories in the region
Label: en

Data: After the Japanese surrender the Brooke family and the British North Borneo Company gave up their control of Sarawak and North Borneo respectively, and these became British Crown Colonies
Label: en

Data: They were much less economically developed than Malaya, and their local political leaderships were too weak to demand independence
Label: en

Data: Singapore, with its large Chinese majority, achieved autonomy in 1955, and in 1959 the young leader Lee Kuan Yew became Prime Minister
Label: en

Data: The Sultan of Brunei remained as a British client in his oil-rich enclave
Label: en

Data: Between 1959 and 1962 the British government orchestrated complex negotiations between these local leaders and the Malayan government
Label: en

Data: On 24 April 1961, Lee Kuan Yew proposed the idea of forming Malaysia during a meeting to Tunku Abdul Rahman, after which Tunku invited Lee to prepare a paper elaborating on this idea
Label: en

Data: On 9 May, Lee sent the final version of the paper to Tunku and then deputy Malayan Prime Minister Abdul Razak
Label: en

Data: There were doubts about the practicality of the idea but Lee assured the Malayan government of continued Malay political dominance in the new federation
Label: en

Data: Razak supported the idea of the new federation and worked to convince Tunku to back it
Label: en

Data: On 27 May 1961, Abdul Rahman proposed the idea of forming "Malaysia", which would consist of Brunei, Malaya, North Borneo, Sarawak, and Singapore, all except Malaya still under British rule
Label: en

Data: It was stated that this would allow the central government to better control and combat communist activities, especially in Singapore
Label: en

Data: It was also feared that if Singapore became independent, it would become a base for Chinese chauvinists to threaten Malayan sovereignty
Label: en

Data: The proposed inclusion of British territories besides Singapore was intended to keep the ethnic composition of the new nation similar to that of Malaya, with the Malay and indigenous populations of the other territories canceling out the Chinese majority in Singapore
Label: en

Data: Although Lee Kuan Yew supported the proposal, his opponents from the Singaporean Socialist Front (Barisan Sosialis) resisted, arguing that this was a ploy for the British to continue controlling the region
Label: en

Data: Most political parties in Sarawak were also against the merger, and in North Borneo, where there were no political parties, community representatives also stated their opposition
Label: en

Data: Although the Sultan of Brunei supported the merger, the Parti Rakyat Brunei opposed it as well
Label: en

Data: At the Commonwealth Prime Ministers Conference in 1961, Abdul Rahman explained his proposal further to its opponents
Label: en

Data: In October, he obtained agreement from the British government to the plan, provided that feedback be obtained from the communities involved in the merger
Label: en

Data: The Cobbold Commission, named after its head, Lord Cobbold, conducted a study in the Borneo territories and approved a merger with North Borneo and Sarawak; however, it was found that a substantial number of Bruneians opposed merger
Label: en

Data: North Borneo drew up a list of points, referred to as the 20-point agreement, proposing terms for its inclusion in the new federation
Label: en

Data: Sarawak prepared a similar memorandum, known as the 18-point agreement
Label: en

Data: Some of the points in these agreements were incorporated into the eventual constitution, some were instead accepted orally
Label: en

Data: These memoranda are often cited by those who believe that Sarawak's and North Borneo's rights have been eroded over time
Label: en

Data: A referendum was conducted in Singapore to gauge opinion, and 70% supported merger with substantial autonomy given to the state government
Label: en

Data: The Sultanate of Brunei withdrew from the planned merger due to opposition from certain segments of its population as well as arguments over the payment of oil royalties and the status of the sultan in the planned merger
Label: en

Data: Additionally, the Bruneian Parti Rakyat Brunei staged an armed revolt, which, though it was put down, was viewed as potentially destabilising to the new nation
Label: en

Data: After reviewing the Cobbold Commission's findings, the British government appointed the Landsdowne Commission to draft a constitution for Malaysia
Label: en

Data: The eventual constitution was essentially the same as the 1957 constitution, albeit with some rewording; for instance, giving recognition to the special position of the natives of the Borneo States
Label: en

Data: North Borneo, Sarawak and Singapore were also granted some autonomy unavailable to the states of Malaya
Label: en

Data: After negotiations in July 1963, it was agreed that Malaysia would come into being on 31 August 1963, consisting of Malaya, North Borneo, Sarawak, and Singapore
Label: en

Data: The date was to coincide with the independence day of Malaya and the British giving self-rule to Sarawak and North Borneo
Label: en

Data: However, Indonesia and the Philippines strenuously objected to this development, with Indonesia claiming Malaysia represented a form of "neocolonialism" and the Philippines claiming North Borneo as its territory
Label: en

Data: The opposition from the Indonesian government led by Sukarno and attempts by the Sarawak United People's Party delayed the formation of Malaysia
Label: en

Data: Due to these factors, an eight-member UN team was formed to re-ascertain whether North Borneo and Sarawak truly wanted to join Malaysia
Label: en

Data: Malaysia formally came into being on 16 September 1963, consisting of Malaya, North Borneo, Sarawak, and Singapore
Label: en

Data: In 1963 the total population of Malaysia was about 10 million
Label: en

Data: At the time of independence, Malaya had great economic advantages
Label: en

Data: It was among the world's leading producers of three valuable commodities; rubber, tin, and palm oil, and was also a significant iron ore producer
Label: en

Data: These export industries gave the Malayan government a healthy surplus to invest in industrial development and infrastructure projects
Label: en

Data: Like other developing nations in the 1950s and 1960s, Malaya (and later Malaysia) placed great stress on state planning, although UMNO was never a socialist party
Label: en

Data: The First and Second Malayan Plans (1956–1960 and 1961–1965 respectively) stimulated economic growth through state investment in industry and repairing infrastructure such as roads and ports, which had been damaged and neglected during the war and the Emergency
Label: en

Data: The government was keen to reduce Malaya's dependence on commodity exports, which put the country at the mercy of fluctuating prices
Label: en

Data: The government was also aware that demand for natural rubber was bound to fall as the production and use of synthetic rubber expanded
Label: en

Data: Since a third of the Malay workforce worked in the rubber industry it was important to develop alternative sources of employment
Label: en

Data: Competition for Malaya's rubber markets meant that the profitability of the rubber industry increasingly depended on keeping wages low, which perpetuated rural Malay poverty
Label: en

Data: Foreign objection Both Indonesia and the Philippines withdrew their ambassadors from Malaya on 15 September 1963, the day before Malaysia's formation
Label: en

Data: In Jakarta the British and Malayan embassies were stoned, and the British consulate in Medan was ransacked with Malaya's consul taking refuge in the US consulate
Label: en

Data: Malaysia withdrew its ambassadors in response, and asked Thailand to represent Malaysia in both countries
Label: en

Data: Indonesian President Sukarno, backed by the powerful Communist Party of Indonesia (PKI), chose to regard Malaysia as a "neocolonialist" plot against his country, and backed a Communist insurgency in Sarawak, mainly involving elements of the local Chinese community
Label: en

Data: Indonesian irregular forces were infiltrated into Sarawak, where they were contained by Malaysian and Commonwealth of Nations forces
Label: en

Data: This period of Konfrontasi, an economic, political, and military confrontation lasted until the downfall of Sukarno in 1966
Label: en

Data: The Philippines objected to the formation of the federation, claiming North Borneo was part of Sulu, and thus the Philippines
Label: en

Data: In 1966 the new president, Ferdinand Marcos, dropped the claim, although it has since been revived and is still a point of contention marring Philippine–Malaysian relations
Label: en

Data: There is massive migration of Chavacanos (Spanish Creole speaking Peruvian-Filipinos from the brief rebel-state of the Republic of Zamboanga), Tausugs, and Sama-Bajaus (Of the Sultanate of Sulu) from the Philippines to Sabah, Malaysia, especially at Semporna, due to them being refugees of the Moro conflict, a war in the Philippines which is primarily supported by the government of Malaysia
Label: en

Data: This war was waged to counteract reconquest attempts from the Philippine Sultanate of Sulu
Label: en

Data: Among the Philippine armed attempts include the 2013 Lahad Datu standoff
Label: en

Data: Racial strife The Depression of the 1930s, followed by the outbreak of the Sino-Japanese War, had the effect of ending Chinese emigration to Malaya
Label: en

Data: This stabilised the demographic situation and ended the prospect of the Malays becoming a minority in their own country
Label: en

Data: At the time of independence in 1957, Malays comprised 55% of the population, Chinese 35% and Indians 10%
Label: en

Data: This balance was altered by the inclusion of the majority-Chinese Singapore, upsetting many Malays
Label: en

Data: The federation increased the Chinese proportion to close to 40%
Label: en

Data: Both UMNO and the MCA were nervous about the possible appeal of Lee's People's Action Party (then seen as a radical socialist party) to voters in Malaya and tried to organise a party in Singapore to challenge Lee's position there
Label: en

Data: Lee in turn threatened to run PAP candidates in Malaya at the 1964 federal elections, despite an earlier agreement that he would not do so (see PAP–UMNO Relations)
Label: en

Data: Racial tensions intensified as PAP created an opposition alliance aiming for equality between races
Label: en

Data: This provoked Tunku Abdul Rahman to demand that Singapore withdraw from Malaysia
Label: en

Data: While the Singaporean leaders attempted to keep Singapore as a part of the Federation, the Malaysian Parliament voted 126–0 on 9 August 1965 in favour of the expulsion of Singapore
Label: en

Data: The most vexed issues of independent Malaysia were education and the disparity of economic power among the ethnic communities
Label: en

Data: The Malays felt unhappy with the wealth of the Chinese community, even after the expulsion of Singapore
Label: en

Data: Malay political movements emerged based around this
Label: en

Data: However, since there was no effective opposition party, these issues were contested mainly within the coalition government, which won all but one seat in the first post-independence Malayan Parliament
Label: en

Data: The two issues were related since the Chinese advantage in education played a large part in maintaining their control of the economy, which the UMNO leaders were determined to end
Label: en

Data: The MCA leaders were torn between the need to defend their own community's interests and the need to maintain good relations with UMNO
Label: en

Data: This produced a crisis in the MCA in 1959, in which a more assertive leadership under Lim Chong Eu defied UMNO over the education issue, only to be forced to back down when Tunku Abdul Rahman threatened to break up the coalition
Label: en

Data: The Education Act of 1961 put UMNO's victory on the education issue into legislative form
Label: en

Data: Henceforward Malay and English would be the only teaching languages in secondary schools, and state primary schools would teach in Malay only
Label: en

Data: Although the Chinese and Indian communities could maintain their own Chinese and Tamil-language primary schools, all their students were required to learn Malay, and to study an agreed "Malayan curriculum"
Label: en

Data: Most importantly, the entrance exam to the University of Malaya (which moved from Singapore to Kuala Lumpur in 1963) would be conducted in Malay, even though most teachings at the university was in English until the 1970s
Label: en

Data: This had the effect of excluding many Chinese students
Label: en

Data: At the same time, Malay schools were heavily subsidised, and Malays were given preferential treatment
Label: en

Data: This obvious defeat for the MCA greatly weakened its support in the Chinese community
Label: en

Data: As in education, the UMNO government's unspoken agenda in the field of economic development aimed to shift economic power away from the Chinese and towards the Malays
Label: en

Data: The two Malayan Plans and the First Malaysian Plan (1966–1970) directed resources heavily into developments that would benefit the rural Malay community, such as village schools, rural roads, clinics, and irrigation projects
Label: en

Data: Several agencies were set up to enable Malay smallholders to upgrade their production and to increase their incomes
Label: en

Data: The Federal Land Development Authority (FELDA) helped many Malays to buy farms or to upgrade ones they already owned
Label: en

Data: The state also provided a range of incentives and low-interest loans to help Malays start businesses, and government tendering systematically favoured Malay companies, leading many Chinese-owned businesses to "Malayanise" their management
Label: en

Data: All this certainly tended to reduce the gap between Chinese and Malay standards of living, although some argued that this would have happened anyway as Malaysia's trade and general prosperity increased
Label: en

Data: Crisis of 1969 and Communist insurgency The collaboration of the MCA and the MIC in these policies weakened their hold on the Chinese and Indian electorates
Label: en

Data: At the same time, the effects of the government's affirmative action policies of the 1950s and 1960s had been to create a discontented class of educated but underemployed Malays
Label: en

Data: This was a dangerous combination and led to the formation of a new party, the Malaysian People's Movement (Gerakan Rakyat Malaysia) in 1968
Label: en

Data: Gerakan was a deliberately non-communal party, bringing in Malay trade unionists and intellectuals as well as Chinese and Indian leaders
Label: en

Data: At the same time, an Islamist party, the Islamic Party of Malaysia (PAS) and a Democratic socialist party, the Democratic Action Party (DAP), gained increasing support, at the expense of UMNO and the MCA respectively
Label: en

Data: Following the end of the Malayan Emergency in 1960, the predominantly ethnic Chinese Malayan National Liberation Army, the armed wing of the Malayan Communist Party, had retreated to the Malaysian-Thailand border where it had regrouped and retrained for future offensives against the Malaysian government
Label: en

Data: The insurgency officially began when the MCP ambushed security forces in Kroh–Betong, in the northern part of Peninsular Malaysia, on 17 June 1968
Label: en

Data: Instead of declaring a "state of emergency" as the British had done previously, the Malaysian government responded to the insurgency by introducing several policy initiatives including the Security and Development Program (KESBAN), Rukun Tetangga (Neighbourhood Watch), and the RELA Corps (People's Volunteer Group)
Label: en

Data: At the May 1969 federal elections, the UMNO-MCA-MIC Alliance polled only 48% of the vote, although it retained a majority in the legislature
Label: en

Data: The MCA lost most of the Chinese-majority seats to Gerakan or DAP candidates
Label: en

Data: The victorious opposition celebrated by holding a motorcade on the main streets of Kuala Lumpur with supporters holding up brooms as a signal of its intention to make sweeping changes
Label: en

Data: Fear of what the changes might mean for them (as much of the country's businesses were Chinese-owned), a Malay backlash resulted, leading rapidly to riots and inter-communal violence in which about 6,000 Chinese homes and businesses were burned and at least 184 people were killed, although Western diplomatic sources at the time suggested a toll of close to 600, with most of the victims are Chinese
Label: en

Data: The government declared a state of emergency, and a National Operations Council, headed by Deputy Prime Minister Tun Abdul Razak, took power from the government of Tunku Abdul Rahman, who, in September 1970, was forced to retire in favour of Abdul Razak
Label: en

Data: It consisted of nine members, mostly Malay, and wielded full political and military power
Label: en

Data: Using the Emergency-era Internal Security Act (ISA), the new government suspended Parliament and political parties, imposed press censorship and placed severe restrictions on political activity
Label: en

Data: The ISA gave the government power to intern any person indefinitely without trial
Label: en

Data: These powers were widely used to silence the government's critics, and have never been repealed
Label: en

Data: The Constitution was changed to make illegal any criticism, even in Parliament, of the Malaysian monarchy, the special position of Malays in the country, or the status of Malay as the national language
Label: en

Data: In 1971, the Parliament reconvened, and a new government coalition, the Barisan Nasional, was formed in 1973 to replace the Alliance party
Label: en

Data: The coalition consisted of UMNO, the MCA, the MIC, Gerakan, PPP, and regional parties in Sabah and Sarawak
Label: en

Data: The PAS also joined the Front but was expelled in 1977
Label: en

Data: The DAP was left outside as the only significant opposition party
Label: en

Data: Abdul Razak held office until he passed away in 1976
Label: en

Data: He was succeeded by Datuk Hussein Onn, the son of UMNO's founder Onn Jaafar, and then by Tun Mahathir Mohamad, who had been Education Minister since 1981, and who held power for 22 years
Label: en

Data: During these years policies were put in place which led to the rapid transformation of Malaysia's economy and society, such as the controversial New Economic Policy, which was intended to increase proportionally the share of the economic "pie" of the bumiputras as compared to other ethnic groups—was launched by Prime Minister Tun Abdul Razak
Label: en

Data: Malaysia has since maintained a delicate ethno-political balance, with a system of government that has attempted to combine overall economic development with political and economic policies that promote equitable participation of all races
Label: en

Data: In 1970 three-quarters of Malaysians living below the poverty line were Malays, the majority of Malays were still rural workers, and Malays were still largely excluded from the modern economy
Label: en

Data: The government's response was the New Economic Policy of 1971, which was to be implemented through a series of four five-year plans from 1971 to 1990
Label: en

Data: The plan had two objectives: the elimination of poverty, particularly rural poverty, and the elimination of the identification between race and prosperity
Label: en

Data: This latter policy was understood to mean a decisive shift in economic power from the Chinese to the Malays, who until then made up only 5% of the professional class
Label: en

Data: To find jobs for all these new Malay graduates, the government created several agencies for intervention in the economy
Label: en

Data: The most important of these were PERNAS (National Corporation Ltd.), PETRONAS (National Petroleum Ltd.), and HICOM (Heavy Industry Corporation of Malaysia), which not only directly employed many Malays but also invested in growing areas of the economy to create new technical and administrative jobs which were preferentially allocated to Malays
Label: en

Data: As a result, the share of Malay equity in the economy rose from 1.5% in 1969 to 20.3% in 1990, and the percentage of businesses of all kinds owned by Malays rose from 39 percent to 68 percent
Label: en

Data: This latter figure was deceptive because many businesses that appeared to be Malay-owned were still indirectly controlled by Chinese, but there is no doubt that the Malay share of the economy considerably increased
Label: en

Data: The Chinese remained disproportionately powerful in Malaysian economic life, but by 2000 the distinction between Chinese and Malay business was fading as many new corporations, particularly in growth sectors such as information technology, were owned and managed by people from both ethnic groups
Label: en

Data: Mahathir Mohamad was sworn in as prime minister on 16 July 1981, at the age of 56
Label: en

Data: One of his first acts was to release 21 detainees held under the Internal Security Act, including journalist Samad Ismail and a former deputy minister in Hussein's government, Abdullah Ahmad, who had been suspected of being an underground communist
Label: en

Data: He appointed his close ally, Musa Hitam, as deputy prime minister
Label: en

Data: The expiry of the Malaysian New Economic Policy (NEP) in 1990 allowed Mahathir to outline his economic vision for Malaysia
Label: en

Data: In 1991, he announced Vision 2020, under which Malaysia would aim to become a fully developed country within 30 years
Label: en

Data: The target would require average economic growth of approximately seven per cent of the gross domestic product per annum
Label: en

Data: One of Vision 2020's features would be to gradually break down ethnic barriers
Label: en

Data: Vision 2020 was accompanied by the NEP's replacement, the National Development Policy (NDP), under which some government programs designed to benefit the Bumiputera exclusively were opened up to other ethnicities
Label: en

Data: The NDP achieved success in one of its main aims, poverty reduction
Label: en

Data: By 1995, less than nine per cent of Malaysians lived in poverty, and income inequality had narrowed
Label: en

Data: Mahathir's government cut corporate taxes and liberalised financial regulations to attract foreign investment
Label: en

Data: The economy grew by over nine per cent per annum until 1997, prompting other developing countries to emulate Mahathir's policies
Label: en

Data: Much of the credit for Malaysia's economic development in the 1990s went to Anwar Ibrahim, appointed by Mahathir as finance minister in 1991
Label: en

Data: The government rode the economic wave and won the 1995 election with an increased majority
Label: en

Data: Mahathir initiated a series of major infrastructure projects in the 1990s
Label: en

Data: One of the largest was the Multimedia Super Corridor, an area south of Kuala Lumpur, in the mould of Silicon Valley, designed to cater for the information technology industry
Label: en

Data: However, the project failed to generate the investment anticipated
Label: en

Data: Other Mahathir's projects included the development of Putrajaya as the home of Malaysia's public service and bringing a Formula One Grand Prix to Sepang
Label: en

Data: One of the most controversial developments was the Bakun Dam in Sarawak
Label: en

Data: The ambitious hydroelectric project was intended to carry electricity across the South China Sea to satisfy electricity demand in peninsular Malaysia
Label: en

Data: Work on the dam was eventually suspended due to the Asian financial crisis
Label: en

Data: In 1997, the Asian financial crisis, which began in Thailand in July 1997, threatened to devastate Malaysia
Label: en

Data: The value of the ringgit plummeted due to currency speculation, foreign investment fled, and the main stock exchange index fell by over 75 per cent
Label: en

Data: At the urging of the International Monetary Fund (IMF), the government cut government spending
Label: en

Data: It raised interest rates, which only served to exacerbate the economic situation
Label: en

Data: In 1998, in a controversial approach, Mahathir reversed this policy course in defiance of the IMF and his own deputy, Anwar
Label: en

Data: He increased government spending and fixed the ringgit to the US dollar
Label: en

Data: The result confounded his international critics and the IMF
Label: en

Data: Malaysia recovered from the crisis faster than its Southeast Asian neighbours
Label: en

Data: In the domestic sphere, it was a political triumph
Label: en

Data: Amidst the economic events of 1998, Mahathir dismissed Anwar as finance minister and deputy prime minister
Label: en

Data: He could now claim to have rescued the economy despite Anwar's policies
Label: en

Data: Shortly after Anwar was dismissed by Mahathir, Anwar and his supporters initiated the Reformasi movement
Label: en

Data: It consisted of several mass demonstrations and rallies against the long-standing Barisan Nasional coalition government
Label: en

Data: He was jailed in April 1999 after a trial for sodomy that was criticised by human rights groups and several foreign governments
Label: en

Data: At UMNO's general assembly in 2002, Mahathir announced that he would resign as prime minister, only for supporters to rush to the stage and convince him tearfully to remain
Label: en

Data: He subsequently fixed his retirement for October 2003, giving him time to ensure an orderly and uncontroversial transition to his anointed successor, Abdullah Badawi
Label: en

Data: Having spent over 22 years in office, Mahathir was the world's longest-serving elected leader when he retired
Label: en

Data: Abdullah Ahmad Badawi promised to combat corruption when he became the fifth Prime Minister, thus empowering anti-corruption agencies and providing more avenues for the public to expose corrupt practices
Label: en

Data: He advocated an interpretation of Islam known as Islam Hadhari, which advocates the intercompatibility between Islam and economic and technological development
Label: en

Data: His administration also placed a strong emphasis on reviving Malaysia's agriculture industry
Label: en

Data: At the 2004 general election, the Barisan Nasional led by Abdullah Badawi had a massive victory, virtually wiping out the PAS and KEADILAN, although the DAP recovered the seats it had lost in 1999
Label: en

Data: This victory was seen as the result mainly of Abdullah's personal popularity and the strong recovery of Malaysia's economy, which has lifted the living standards of many Malaysians, coupled with an ineffective opposition
Label: en

Data: Former Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim, upon his release from prison in September 2004, publicly credited Abdullah Badawi for not interfering with the court's overturning of his sodomy conviction
Label: en

Data: In November 2007, Malaysia saw two anti-government rallies
Label: en

Data: The 2007 Bersih Rally was held in Kuala Lumpur on 10 November 2007, to campaign for electoral reform
Label: en

Data: It was precipitated by allegations of corruption and discrepancies in the Malaysian election system that heavily favoured the ruling political party, Barisan Nasional, which had been in power since 1973
Label: en

Data: Another rally was held in the same month, on 25 November 2007, in Kuala Lumpur led by Hindu Rights Action Force (HINDRAF)
Label: en

Data: HINDRAF had called the protest over alleged discriminatory policies favouring ethnic Malays
Label: en

Data: In both cases, the government and police tried to prevent the gatherings from taking place
Label: en

Data: On 15 October 2008, HINDRAF was banned when the government labelled the organisation as a threat to national security
Label: en

Data: Abdullah Badawi was re-elected as the prime minister in the 2008 general election, which took place in March 2008, with a reduced majority
Label: en

Data: In the election, his party, Barisan Nasional won a slim majority of seats but lost its two-thirds majority and five states to Opposition Pact
Label: en

Data: Although Barisan Nasional, suffered a significant setback, Abdullah Badawi vowed to fulfil the promises in his manifesto amid calls from Mahathir, the opposition and even among UMNO members for him to resign
Label: en

Data: However, his Deputy Prime Minister, Najib Razak, and others in his party voiced unequivocal support for his leadership
Label: en

Data: It took some time before there was open dissent at the grassroots level, leading to the creation of petitions and campaigns calling for his resignation
Label: en

Data: Abdullah came under growing criticism, primarily because of his failure to combat corruption and his subpar performance in the 2008 Malaysian general election
Label: en

Data: Hence, in October 2008, he announced his intention to resign the following March
Label: en

Data: Abdullah was succeeded in office by his deputy, Najib Razak (son of Abdul Razak), in April 2009
Label: en

Data: 1Malaysia campaign was introduced by Najib Razak in the summer of 2009
Label: en

Data: On 15 September 2011, Najib announced that the Internal Security Act 1960 will be repealed and replaced by two new laws
Label: en

Data: The ISA was replaced and repealed by the Security Offences (Special Measures) Act 2012 which has been passed by Parliament and given royal assent on 18 June 2012
Label: en

Data: The Act came into force on 31 July 2012
Label: en

Data: In January 2012, the 2008 charges against Anwar Ibrahim, which Anwar had always maintained that they were part of a political smear campaign, were dismissed after a two-year trial, but an appeals court subsequently overturned this acquittal in 2014, and he was sentenced to five years in prison
Label: en

Data: In 2015, he was sent to Sungai Buloh Prison, Selangor, to serve the sentence
Label: en

Data: In early February 2013, there was an incursion in Lahad Datu, a military conflict that began when hundreds of militants, some of whom were armed, arrived by boats in Lahad Datu District, Sabah, Malaysia from Simunul Island, Tawi-Tawi, in the southern Philippines
Label: en

Data: The group was sent by Jamalul Kiram III, one of the claimants to the throne of the Sultanate of Sulu
Label: en

Data: In response to the incursion, Malaysian security forces launched a major operation to repel the militants, resulting in a decisive Malaysian victory which ended the conflict in late March 2013
Label: en

Data: Following the elimination of militants, the Eastern Sabah Security Command (ESSCOM) was established
Label: en

Data: On March 8, 2014, Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 vanished en route from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing
Label: en

Data: The 239 passengers and crew on board were presumed dead
Label: en

Data: Just four months later, 298 people were killed when Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 was shot down by a surface-to-air missile while flying over territory controlled by Russian-backed militants in Eastern Ukraine
Label: en

Data: On 1 April 2015, Najib passed a controversial 6 per cent tax on goods and services
Label: en

Data: Later that year, his administration was engulfed in scandal when Najib and other officials were implicated in a multibillion-dollar embezzlement and money-laundering scheme involving 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB), a state-owned investment fund masterminded by Low Taek Jho, triggering widespread calls and protests from most Malaysians including the opposition parties for Najib's resignation
Label: en

Data: These protests culminated in the Malaysian Citizens' Declaration by Mahathir Mohamad, Pakatan Harapan and NGOs which sought to oust Najib
Label: en

Data: The Bersih movement also held four rallies from 2011 to 2016 during the Najib administration intending to reform Malaysia's existing electoral system to achieve free, transparent, and fair elections
Label: en

Data: The movement expanded its demands to include issues such as clean governance and human rights
Label: en

Data: Najib had also been criticised for the lavish lifestyle of his wife Rosmah Mansor
Label: en

Data: In response to accusations of corruption, Najib tightened his hold on power by removing Muhyiddin Yassin, the deputy prime minister at the time, suspending two newspapers, and forcing through the parliaments the controversial National Security Council Bill, which gives the prime minister unprecedented powers
Label: en

Data: Living costs have skyrocketed as a result of Najib's numerous subsidy cuts, while the Malaysian ringgit has declined due to fluctuating oil prices and the 1MDB scandal's effects
Label: en

Data: After Barisan Nasional lost the 2018 general elections, these came to an end
Label: en

Data: Relations between Malaysia and North Korea deteriorated in 2017, in the aftermath of the assassination of Kim Jong-nam in Malaysia, which made global headlines and sparked a major diplomatic row between the two countries
Label: en

Data: Mahathir Mohamad, who left UMNO in 2016 and formed his own political party, the Malaysian United Indigenous Party (BERSATU), which teamed up with three other political parties to form Pakatan Harapan, was sworn in as the seventh Prime Minister of Malaysia after winning the election on 10 May 2018
Label: en

Data: Washington also demanded that Americans would have equal rights with Filipinos in business activities, a special treatment that was resented
